column4: tell me more about your setup.  The nas box is behind a router, I assume.

i have a similar problem that sup3rs3nior had. I have an NAS with ftp/smb running, i have installed ssh, i have dyndns setup for my ip but i need to know how to connect to my NAS through the dyndns address
yes
i'm looking to be able to FTP through ssh so i can access it out of network, like from a coffee shop
The dyndns server is equating a dns name for the world to your ip address on the router.  What is it you want to have connected to the outside world?  Is it the ftp?
yes i want to be able to access my NAS over FTP from the dyndns
and through ssh
We'll start with ftp.  Do you want to use the standard ports for ftp?  I'll assume yes for the moment.  You need to go into your router and setup forwarding rules for ports 20 and 21.
you assume correctly. i have them forwarded now.
If you want to forward ssh, it is similar.  If you use the standard ports, it is port 22.
i want to forward my current computer's ip or the NAS ip
I don't know what ftp server you are using.  Some are vulnerable to hacking.  vsftpd is pretty safe.  If you are not using a good one, I would not leave those ftp ports open all the time.
i don't know either haha
it's just the server that came with the NAS box
You have to pick one to forward to.  But, each port can be different.  You can forwart port 8124 on the external port of your router to port 22 on your machine and port 8125 to port 22 of the NAS.
Then, I would assume it is pretty hackable.
so i wouldn't want to do this or what

I would not leave a relatively insecure ftp server exposed to the internet all the time.  Leave it set up and just turn on the forwarding rules for a brief time when a friend needs to upload.  Or, use a better ftp daemon on another machine.  Or configure port knocking on your router(not for beginners)
well it can only be seen from inside the network i just want a way to connect to it via ftp securely. i would have to do those things if i wanted to do that?
I don't understand.  If you mean, you don't need port forward rules for use inside the LAN, then you are correct.
right, but i can set the FTP port on the NAS so wouldn't that narrow my chances of being hacked
It helps a little.  A good port scanner will still find it.
and passwords don't do anything to stop them either
